ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I study LCA and am interested in focusing on whole-building LCA upon leaving school. Was a good intro, but would have like more in depth study of building science. Include more technical calculations and materials.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trip. Readings.
Field trip, speakers, excellent instructor.

The field trip was amazing! It was so much more helpful to learn about buildings by walking through them. Peter introduced us to some very interesting people and concepts. I fully support another field trip next year, and possibly a second (though not another weekend). True to his word, Peter provides a strong overview of green building. It's a shame that there's not more time to go deeper into topics, but, this is FES, not an architecture or structural engineering program. It's the appropriate amount for policymakers, business managers, etc.

The way the major assignments are structured and open for integration. This allows the student to approach a topic of interest from multiple perspectives (literary review, career path, practical applications).
The field trip and the visiting lecturers were very helpful and added to the great basic information discussed during the lecture classes.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Would have liked a more rigorous lecture style, where we covered more material.

The online quizzes felt like busy work. A better way of assessing the students' reading comprehension would have been to have more class discussions about it. A building science intensive would be very valuable to students without much background in buildings/construction.

Peter is great, but his lectures are just too scattered. He goes on tangents, spends 20 minutes in the beginning of class telling us his plan, doesn't stick to it, etc. Peter also repeatedly said throughout the semester that he wasn't concerned with when we turned in assignments, only that we turn them all in before the end of the semester. Then, all of sudden, he started enforcing due dates and taking points off for turning in assignments late. It was unexpected and unfair. Either stick to due dates, or stick to your word that we can turn them in on our own schedule, so long as they're all done by the end of the course. Either option is fine, but don't try to do both, which detracts from student learning rather than enhances it. One thing I would like to see is a tie-in with the LEED GA exam. I figure it wouldn't take too much extra studying for a student who's taken this course to pass that exam. if FES were to pay for or subsidize the exam, that might be a nice bonus accreditation for students interested in green building to have on their resumes.
More connections between the reading material and the in-class discussion. Bringing guest speakers was valuable but they cut the progression of materials being covered.

Like we discussed in class, it would be helpful to address all the basic building science material early so that everyone is on the same page. Then a more in depth discussion of the advanced concepts is possible.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: If you work on public health or energy issues, you should know how buildings work and what our best-in-class buildings do for human and environmental well-being.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Wanted to build a foundation of knowledge in green building.
I felt it filled a gap in my knowledge.
Wanted to have a better understanding of the Green Buildings concept.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Would have like more technical material as discussed above. Like the open format of the final project, which really allows us to pursue a topic of interest to us and our future.
Yes

Mostly. It would be helpful to talk about the material a bit more in class so that we can solidify that knowledge. If I've read something once without discussing it, I'll be much more likely to forget it. Also, Peter assigns a few too many readings, which makes it difficult to focus on any one of them. Skimming 5 readings is not as helpful as reading 3.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: Interact with classmates with different backgrounds and working styles. Good feedback and suggestions to improve the approach taken and the deliverables.

I have had a lot of experience working in groups while at Yale. It was helpful to have a group to address a larger topic with the level of detail required of a final project. The group work proceeded smoothly and the final product was high quality.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Communicate your interests to the teacher and he will probably respond and focus effort on those topics!
Take it!

It is a survey class that exposes you to several topics that are part of the Green Buildings concept. The major assignments for the class can be easily integrated, which allows you to take a deeper dive into a topic from various perspectives and also benefit from reduced workload.
